utterances: All right.
Dale, thanks very much for the call.
We wish you better luck.
Yeah, it did.
And is it possible, do you think - it's so difficult for people to make jokes about Barack Obama.
Well, it's kind of funny, I mean, you know, everybody has, you know, we...
Except for you.
Well, we - no. We joked about Bill Clinton and women.
We joked about Hillary Clinton.
We're certainly still joking about George W.
Bush.
There's plenty of jokes about that.
But it seems like the Barack Obama candidacy is either very sensitive, or the candidate doesn't lend himself to that kind of humor.
There's something funny...
(Soundbite of music)
I hear music.
Yes, ""How High the Moon.
Then I'm going to stop.
OK.
Ken Rudin will be back with us.
You come back, too.
We're just going to take a short break.
If you'd like to join the conversation, we're going to be reviewing the two candidates' speeches to the NAACP, and then talking about the great political insults and put-downs of all time.
If you've got a favorite, give us a call, 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is Talk of the Nation.
I'm Neal Conan, and we're broadcasting today from the Knight Studio inside the Newseum in Washington, D.C., and you're listening to our Wednesday edition of the Political Junkie.
As always, NPR political editor, Ken Rudin, is with us.
In just a moment, we're going to be talking about the candidates' address to the NAACP convention, but Ken, before the break, you had a funny story about Barack Obama.

Well, it's not a funny story that I've come up with, but Andy Borowitz - who I think is one of the funniest people in the world, a great comedian - he says that, you know, obviously there are not many jokes about Barack Obama.
So, Barack Obama himself - now, this is all tongue-in-cheek - has approved several jokes, and let me just read you two of them.
Barack Obama and a kangaroo pull up to a gas station.
The gas station attendant takes one look at the kangaroo and says, you know, we don't get many kangaroos here.
Barack Obama replies, at these prices, I'm not surprised.
That's why we need to reduce our dependence on foreign oil.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And the other one.
A horse walks into a bar.
The bartender says, why the long face?
Barack Obama says, his jockey just lost his health insurance, and that should be the right of all Americans.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Wacky jokes, huh?
Not just...
They're really just hysterically funny.
We're just slaying him here, yeah.
(Soundbite of laughter)
The NAACP annual convention is taking place this week in Cincinnati, Ohio.
This morning, Senator John McCain addressed its membership at the Duke Energy Center.
(Soundbite of McCain campaign speech, July 16, 2008)
So, whatever the outcome in November, Senator Obama has achieved a great thing for himself and his country, and I thank him for it.
Don't tell him I said this...
(Soundbite of laughter)
But he's an impressive fellow in many ways.
(Soundbite of applause)
Senator John McCain, the prospective Republican presidential nominee, who spoke this morning in Cincinnati at the NAACP annual convention.
Kelly Brewington, the diversity and demographics reporter for the Baltimore Sun, was there, and she was there when Senator Barack Obama spoke to the convention.
And she joins us now by phone from Cincinnati, and Kelly Brewington, nice to have you on Talk of the Nation today.
And give us a sense of how Senator McCain was received today?
You know, it was interesting.
People were very polite.
They were engaged and excited to see the candidate, but they were not exceptionally enthused by his remarks.
There was - he took on an issue that was somewhat unpopular with the NAACP.
He talked about school choice and particularly school vouchers.
People at the NAACP, from the leadership on down, are not very excited about school vouchers.
They don't tend to support the position.
So, there was only smatterings of applause during his 30-minute speech, but he seemed to make a big effort to connect with the audience afterwards.
He did some question-and-answer, and appeared, you know, very at ease and confident, and the audience seemed to appreciate that.
There have been Republican candidates, indeed, sitting Republican presidents, running for reelection who did not address the NAACP.
And were people - did people take note of Senator McCain's effort to show up and, even if he's not going to be necessarily popular, to make an appearance?
Certainly, they did, and they - they noted that.
I mean, as you know, the Bush administration, for many years, for most of its two terms, did not speak to the organization, despite its invitation.
And the NAACP had sort of an icy relationship with the administration.
Things have thawed a bit.
And last year, during its convention in Detroit, the only Republican nominee to address the group was Representative Tom Tancredo, and so, they were excited to see McCain.
I think his presence made them feel as though he was taking the organization seriously, and that their commitment to civil rights was something that was on his agenda.
Ken Rudin?
You know, obviously, everybody at the audience knew that John McCain initially opposed a holiday for Dr. Martin Luther King.
But here's a question I have.

Do you suspect that - and a lot of people suggested this - that perhaps he was not - John McCain was not hoping to win African-American votes, especially against a candidate like Barack Obama, but he was trying to appeal to white Independents, white moderates, to make the point that he's not as conservative as some make him out to be?
Let's see if we can get Leilani (ph) on the line.
Leilani is calling us from - is this Moline, Illinois?
It's Mundelein.
I mean, that could be - that could be true.
I can't say for certain what his objective was.

But it does appear - of late, I think this has been said of both candidates - that they've tried to appeal to the middle a bit, if - whatever the middle might be, but, I guess, away from the traditional Democratic/Republican constituents.
And so, perhaps that was his intent.
I mean, I think he tried to make a lot of overtures at the great work the NAACP has done.
He talked about civil rights and how he appreciated their work for nearly 100 years, and he had, as you played, you know, some kind remarks about Obama.
So, perhaps that's his objective.
I mean, either way, people seemed to appreciate it.
Like I said, they didn't agree with what he was saying, but they appreciated, I think, the...
I think you were right earlier, Kelly Brewington, you said basically golf claps for Senator McCain, thunderous applause earlier in the week for Barack Obama.
Oh, certainly.
I mean, I think Obama's reception was - it was electric.
I mean, people waited many hours through to pass through a metal detector to get into the ballroom of the Duke Energy Center.
They wore buttons with Obama's name on it and t-shirts, and they were standing on their feet shouting and applauding during many of his remarks.

I mean, there's no doubt that there's a sense of pride that people are feeling here, that Obama's candidacy is, for many of them, a civil rights milestone, regardless of where they stand politically, that this civil rights sort of, you know, - his candidacy represents a civil rights milestone, which is a cause for celebration in their minds.
Kelly Brewington, thanks so much for your time today.
We appreciate it.
Sure, thanks for having me.
Kelly Brewington, diversity and demographics reporter for the Baltimore Sun, with us by phone from the NAACP annual conference in Cincinnati, Ohio.
Well, time was - the well-timed political insult was part of a politician's stock-in-trade.
The revered figure of Abraham Lincoln delighted in describing one opponent, he can compress the most words into the smallest idea of any man I know.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Political zingers stung.

And while everybody remembers one or two of Winston Churchill's finest, yes, but I'll be sober in the morning, 21st century politicians are careful to keep their rapier wit sheathed and do battle with powder puffs.
Here's a couple of examples of the blunted swordplay we've seen this political cycle.
(Soundbite of ABC News broadcast, Democratic Primary Debate, January 5, 2008)
He's very likable.
I agree with that.
I don't think I'm that bad...
You're likable enough, Hillary.
No doubt about it.
Thank you so much.
(Soundbite of laughter)
